headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2016 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions].Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in this presentati
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2016 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions].
Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in this presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time they are made.
In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with the statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussions, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share, unless otherwise noted.
After the presentation, the conference will be open to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, a package of detailed financial information is posted at WEC wecenergygroup.com. A replay of our remarks will be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call.
And now it's my pleasure to introduce Allen Leverett, President and Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our results for the third quarter of the year. But first, I want to introduce the members of our team who are with me here today: Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, our T
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our results for the third quarter of the year. But first, I want to introduce the members of our team who are with me here today: Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, our Treasurer; Susan Martin, our General Counsel; Bill Guc, our Controller; Beth Straka, finally, our Senior Vice President our Corporate Communications and Investor Relations.
So with that, let's start with our third quarter 2016 results. We reported adjusted third quarter earnings of $0.69 per share. That compares with adjusted earnings of $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Our adjusted earnings exclude merger-related costs. The weather here in Southeastern Wisconsin was the second warmest in 84 years. Scott will review the most significant drivers for the quarter with you in a moment. In addition to our third quarter earnings, we have 2 positive developments to share with you. First, we reached an uncontested settlement with the Michigan Public Service Commission staff, the Michigan Attorney General and other intervenors to form a Michigan only utility. This utility will be named the Upper Michigan Energy Resources Company, or UMERC for short. We expect UMERC will provide electric and natural gas service to current customers in Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. At this point, we believe UMERC will begin operations on January 1 of next year. The formation of UMERC is another step that is required to allow us to begin a certificate of necessity proceeding for our proposed generation solution in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. We are proposing a $255 million investment and 170 megawatts of natural gas-fired generation. UMERC would own and operate the reciprocating internal combustion engines which would provide a long-term generation solution for reliable and low-cost power for customers in the Upper Peninsula including the mines owned by Presque Resources. Now we expect to file our proposal with the Michigan Commission in November and we're targeting commercial operation in 2019. At that time, or soon after, we expect to be in a position to retire our coal-fired Presque Isle Power Plant. The second positive development relates to our earnings outlook. Based on the positive third quarter results, largely driven by weather, we now expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our guidance range of $2.88 to $2.94.
Now we only had 1 ongoing rate case this year. This was our Minnesota gas utility's rate case. There we recently received the final decision from the Minnesota Commission authorizing a 9.11% return on equity. The revenue increase is approximately 3% or an estimated $6.8 million. And this is in line with our expectations for the case. Early next year, we will evaluate our rate case plans for all of our utilities. Next, I want to mention a recent development at the FERC level which impacts our earnings at ATC. At September 28, FERC voted to affirm fire ALJ recommendation of a 10.32% base ROE in the first MISO ROE complaint. Effective January 2015, we qualified for a 50 basis point adder for being a MISO number increasing our ROE to 10.82%. The resolution of this first complaint for the period of November 2013 through February 11 of 2015, resulted in an increase in pretax earnings of approximately $1.4 million. Looking ahead, we expect an order in the second quarter of 2017 in the second MISO complaint case for the ALJ recommended a base ROE of 9.7%. Again, we qualified for the 50 basis points adder, which would increase the recommended ROE to 10.2%. We believe this is an appropriate assumption going forward. Now a reminder on our dividend. In January of this year, our board declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.495 a share, an increase of 8.2% over the previous quarterly dividend. Our annual dividend rate stands at $1.98 a share and our yield is at approximately the industry average.
We continue the target of payout ratio of 65% to 70% of earnings. Given that we are in this range now, I expect our dividend growth will be in line with our earnings per share growth.
Finally, I want to review our updated 5-year capital forecast. This plan now reflects a range of $9 billion to $9.5 billion, which is $1.6 billion more than the plan we presented at EEI last November. This plan does not include a potential natural gas storage investment that we are continuing to pursue. I would also remind you that these figures do not include ATC's capital spending plan.
In addition to the projects outlined for you earlier, we had continue to identify a need for deeper infrastructure improvements including our gas facilities in Chicago. We have included updated 5-year capital investment forecast charts in the back of the earnings packet.
Now with the details in our third quarter results and the financial outlook, here's our Chief Financial Officer, Scott Lauber.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Allen. Our 2016 third quarter debt [ph] earnings were $0.68 per share compared with $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Third quarter results in both 2016 and 2015 include a full quarter of earnings from the Integrys companies. Exclud
componenttext:
Thank you, Allen. Our 2016 third quarter debt [ph] earnings were $0.68 per share compared with $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Third quarter results in both 2016 and 2015 include a full quarter of earnings from the Integrys companies. Excluding 1 set of acquisition cost in 2016, adjusted earnings per share increased by $0.11 from $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015 to $0.69 per share in the third quarter of 2016. You may recall that we reported adjusted earnings of $0.61 per share in the third quarter last year. For purposes of comparing 2016 and 2015 third quarter earnings on a consistent basis, the calculation of adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter of 2015 now include Integrys' earnings, all interest expense related to the acquisition financing and all shares issued in conjunction with the acquisition.
As a result, the comparable adjusted earnings per share value for 2015 is now $0.58 per share. The earnings packet placed on our website this morning includes the result of the Integrys companies and its full GAAP to adjusted reconciliation. First, I'll focus on operating income by segment and then discuss other income, interest expense and income taxes.
Returning to Page 10 of the earnings packet, our consolidated operating income for the third quarter adjusted for costs related to the acquisition of Integrys, was $402.5 million, as compared to $351.8 million in 2015, an increase of $50.7 million. Starting with the Wisconsin segment, operating income in the third quarter totaled $299.1 million for 2016, an increase of $42.5 million from the third quarter of 2015. The improved quarter-over-quarter results for the Wisconsin segment was driven primarily by significantly warmer-than-normal weather and timing of positive fuel recoveries. In the third quarter of 2016, our Illinois segment had $11.7 million of operating income, an increase of $8.2 million compared to the $3.5 million of operating income recognized during the 20,153rd quarter.
The increase in operating income was driven primarily by continued investment in the gas system modernization program.
Operating income for our other state segment improved $2.7 million, in part due to cost controls. Operating income at the We Power segment was up $500,000 when compared to 2015. This increase reflect additional investment at our Power the Future plants. Our corporate and other segment realized that adjusted operating loss of $1 million this quarter compared to adjusted operating income of $2.2 million in the third quarter of 2015.
Taking the changes of these segments together, we arrived at $50.7 million increase in adjusted operating income. During the third quarter of 2016, earnings from our investment in American Transmission Company totaled $38.3 million, a decrease of $1.7 million from the same quarter last year. The lower equity earnings were driven by the recent FERC order and ALJ recommendations related to the ATC ROE reviews. Our other income net decreased by $3.6 million largely related to lower AFUDC which was caused primarily by timing of capital expenditures. Our net interest expense decreased $4.1 million. Interest expense decreased quarter-over-quarter primarily as a result of the repurchase of a portion of the Integrys 6.11% union notes earlier this year. Those notes replaced with lower interest rate, short-term debt.
Increased quarter-over-quarter operating income was the primary driver for the $15.7 million increase in our adjusted consolidated income tax expense. We anticipate that our annual effective tax rate for 2016 will be between 37.5% and 38.5%.
Combining all of these items brings us to adjusted earnings of $219.1 million or $0.69 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared to $185 million or $0.58 per share for the third quarter of 2015.
On a year-to-date basis, GAAP earnings were $2.35 per share compared with $1.78 per share the 9 months ended September 30, 2015.
Excluding acquisition costs, adjusted earnings per share increased $0.33 from $2.03 per share in 2015 to $2.36 per share in 2016.
Year-to-date results in 2016 include the impacts of Integrys acquisition. Recall that 2015 year-to-date results include only 1 quarter of Integrys increased $647.5 million during the first 9 months of 2016. This increase was driven primarily by $526 million of net cash flows for the operating activities of Integrys for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016.
The remaining increase was driven by a decrease in contributions to employee benefit plans. As previously discussed, we contribute $100 million to our qualified pension trust in 2015 and we did not make a contribution in 2016.
Our capital expenditures totaled $1 billion during the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, a $208.3 million increase compared to the same period in 2015. The largest increase was related to the capital investments at the Integrys companies.
Our debt-to-capital ratio was 51.4% at the end of September, an increase from the 50.1% adjusted debt-to-capital ratio reported at the end of June. Effective at the end of the third quarter, we no longer are adjusting equity for any portion of the legacy Integrys hybrid instruments.
Our calculations continue to treat half of the WEC Energy Group 2007 series A 2 new subordinate notes of common equity.
We are using cash to satisfy any shares required for our 401-k plans, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares. We also paid $468.6 million in common dividends during the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, an increase of $157.7 million over the same period last year.
Higher dividends were driven by the increase in shares outstanding related to the Integrys acquisition and an increase in the dividend rate compared to the first 9 months of 2015.
Since the beginning of 2015, we increased our quarterly dividend 17.2% from $0.4225 per share to the current level of $0.495 per share. Moving to sales. We continue to see customer growth across our system. At the end of September, our Wisconsin utilities were serving about 7,000 loyal electric customers and nearly 13,000 more natural gas customers compared to 1 year ago. Our natural gas utilities in Illinois, Michigan and Minnesota are serving approximately 18,000 more customers compared to a year ago.
Now let's discuss the levered values. For comparative purposes, year-to-date electric volume information reflects results for both Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service. Weather-normalized deliveries are adjusted to factor out the effects of leap year. Actual third quarter retail electric deliveries, excluding the iron ore mines, increased 4.1%. On a weather-normalized basis, retail deliveries of electricity were flat compared to the third quarter of 2015.
Looking at the individual customer segments. Actual residential deliveries rose 8.1% while weather-normalized residential deliveries decreased 5/10 of 1%.
Across our small commercial industrial group, actual deliveries increased 3.6% while weather-normalized quarterly deliveries increased 7/10 of 1%. In the large commercial and industrial segment, deliveries for the third quarter of 2016 increased 2.2%. Excluding the iron ore mines, large commercial and industrial deliveries increased 8/10 of 1%.
We see continued improvement in several important sectors of Wisconsin economy, including paper and paper products, food processing and chemical processing.
Year-to-date weather-normalized retail deliveries, excluding the iron ore mines, increased 3/10 of 1%.
Now an update on our natural gas deliveries. As you may recall, our Illinois segment has a decoupling mechanism and its margins are less affected by weather. Looking at Wisconsin, our largest segment, year-to-date retail gas deliveries, excluding gas used for power generation, decreased 3% compared to the same period in 2015 due primarily to normal weather.
On a weather-normalized basis, year-to-date retail gas deliveries, excluding gas used for power generation were up 2.8%. Overall, our normalized results for gas and electric sales in 2016 were slightly above our expectations. Turning now to our earnings forecast. We expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our guidance of $2.88 per share to $2.94 per share. The guidance excludes a $0.01 per share acquisition-related cost in the third quarter as well any potential acquisition-related cost that may arise during the quarter.
This projection assumes normal weather for the balance of the year and reflects the mild first quarter weather, as well as the very warm third quarter weather conditions.
A couple of key points as we look at rental guidance. First, the very warm weather in the third quarter was mainly in Southeastern Wisconsin and then majority of the weather-related margins and positive fuel recoveries were in the Wisconsin Electric service territory. This was a benefit to Wisconsin Electric and the third quarter of about $0.08. As you recall, Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas have an earnings sharing mechanism in place as part of the acquisition order and therefore, limit the overall earnings potential for the year.
In addition, we expect an increase in maintenance expense items in the fourth quarter compared to last year. Again, we expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our $2.88 per share to $2.94 per share guidance range. With that, I'll turn things back to Allen.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Now before we take your questions, I want to take a moment to thank Colleen Henderson for her 21 years of dedicated service to the company.Now it's been my pleasure to work with Colleen for 13 of these 21 years. Colleen will be retirin
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Now before we take your questions, I want to take a moment to thank Colleen Henderson for her 21 years of dedicated service to the company.
Now it's been my pleasure to work with Colleen for 13 of these 21 years. Colleen will be retiring from the company in January. Colleen has been our primary contact with all of you as well as the other members of the investment community.
She leaves a legacy what I believe is one of the best Investor Relations programs in our industry. So please join me in wishing Colleen a long, happy and healthy retirement.
Operator, we're ready for the question-and-answer portion of our conference call.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Greg Gordon with Evercore ISI.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to say congratulations as well to Colleen, you'll be missed. I do have a question on the fourth quarter earnings and then a question on CapEx. So first, you guys earned $0.63 in the fourth quarter last year. So if I just do the basic math,
componenttext: First, I wanted to say congratulations as well to Colleen, you'll be missed. I do have a question on the fourth quarter earnings and then a question on CapEx. So first, you guys earned $0.63 in the fourth quarter last year. So if I just do the basic math, if you had flat year, you'd be slightly above the high end of the range is the reason you don't expect that to happen is because you'll be in a refund position on the sharing or because you found opportunities to do accelerated expense programs with a benefit customers? Or some combination of both or is there another item that I'm not thinking about?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start, Greg, on the fourth quarter earnings question then I'll let Scott expand on a couple of points. So you touched on one of the issues which is the sharing mechanism. At Wisconsin Electric when I say sharing mechanism, the earnings sharing m
componenttext: So let me start, Greg, on the fourth quarter earnings question then I'll let Scott expand on a couple of points. So you touched on one of the issues which is the sharing mechanism. At Wisconsin Electric when I say sharing mechanism, the earnings sharing mechanism at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas. And just to keep in mind, that's about 60% of our regulated utilities. So 60% of our earnings would be subject to that earning sharing mechanism. So we certainly expect that mechanism to kick in and there will be some sharing. In fact, we already approved some sharing in the third quarter. So that's in the first factor that will impact, we expect to impact the fourth quarter. You touched on that. The other thing, Greg, that I would just emphasize and Scott talked about this a little bit in his remarks. But remember, the electric fuel recovery mechanisms that we have at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service, they have a dead band. So in dollar terms, it's they have plus or minus $15 million at Wisconsin Electric. It's a plus or minus $6 million at Wisconsin Public Service. And so once you get above those positive recovery levels, all of the dollars go dollar-for-dollar above that level back to refunds for customers. Unlike the third quarter of last year, we actually went all the way to the top of those bands in the third quarter of this year. In the fourth quarter of last year, we have to get well into the fourth quarter before we hit those levels. So that also will introduce another timing indifference or earnings timing difference, if you will, in third quarter as opposed to fourth. and in the last thing is related to the O&M spend. And what really happened, Greg, since like every quarter we talked a lot about the weather but in the fourth quarter of 2015, that was a very mild weather quarter. And as a result, in order to hit the financial commitments we had, we actually had to cut back a bit on O&M spending. So I view the O&M spend run rate that we have in the fourth quarter of 2015 is being a little abnormal, being abnormaly low. What I think we'll see in the fourth quarter of this year is more of a normal run rate for the business the way it's continued now. So I think those 3 factors, the earnings share-ing mechanisms, hitting the top of the positive recovery bands on fuel in the third quarter and finally, that difference in O&M timing, I think all of those will impact the fourth quarter. I don't know, Scott, if you want to spend any time at all on the share-ing mechanisms.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, if we can just cover that just a little bit. So at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas, the sharing mechanism and remember, there's an authorized or allowed return in Wisconsin Electric of about 10.2% ROE and then we share the first 50 basis points
componenttext: Yes, if we can just cover that just a little bit. So at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas, the sharing mechanism and remember, there's an authorized or allowed return in Wisconsin Electric of about 10.2% ROE and then we share the first 50 basis points above that. So we can theoretically earn up to the 10.45. And then anything above that or the share-ing part of it will be used to basically amortize some of the transmission assets that we have on our balance sheet. That was part of the acquisition order. So that's part of the sharing mechanism that will happen and as we look at the fourth quarter again and tie it all to the other. As we look at their earnings in the fourth quarter last year, if you factor in the interest expense it's about $0.62 in the comparable basis and the fuel that Allen talked about, that's about $0.03 so you get down to that $0.59 and the O&M getting back to a normal run rate and maintenance is about $0.02 to $0.03. So it gets into that $0.57, $0.59 range.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, I think you also had a question on capital.
componenttext: So Greg, I think you also had a question on capital.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You did mention it in your comments at the opening of the call. Can you talk a bit more about specifically what kind of projects you've identified? I think at this point, you've pretty much fully offset the $1 billion impact of bonus depreciation fro
componenttext: Yes. You did mention it in your comments at the opening of the call. Can you talk a bit more about specifically what kind of projects you've identified? I think at this point, you've pretty much fully offset the $1 billion impact of bonus depreciation from the tax packet that was passed last December. And I think it even, if I count them -- increases in 2019 and 2020 CapEx forecast are now basically gotten back into sort of positive territory on total rate base addition relative to the impact of bonus. So can you talk about where you are and in your sort of thought process on updating your CapEx? You said there's still, A, what are the things you put into the plan that you think are beneficial to customers? And B, what still -- you talked about I think at least 1 type of capital program that's still under consideration that hasn't been rolled out yet.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay well, in terms of the wider number breakdown, so overall if we look at our 5-year capital plan, it's about $1.6 billion more than the plan that was laid out in November of 2015 at EEI. So you're exactly right, Greg. It would offset roughly $1
componenttext: Right. Okay well, in terms of the wider number breakdown, so overall if we look at our 5-year capital plan, it's about $1.6 billion more than the plan that was laid out in November of 2015 at EEI. So you're exactly right, Greg. It would offset roughly $1 billion cash impact of bonus depreciation plus another, say, $550 million on top of that. So just to give you a sense for the types of things, Greg, that are in the $1.6 billion. So we alluded to one of them in the call, so there's $255 million for the generation in Michigan. I certainly see that as a benefit to the customers and also benefit to the customers in Wisconsin because once we retire Presque Isle, there'll be about a $40 million O&M savings associated with retiring that plan. Also in the generation category, we've made the assumption, we also expect that as soon as we can or allowed to by MISO, we want to proceed to retire the plant which is a coal plant in the Green Bay area and that will lead the generation in Wisconsin Public Service and we'll have an option to invest. We have a generation option to the Riverside Power Plant, and alliance building. That's about $100 million. So exercising that first option. On the electric distribution side, I think we've talked before about the system modernization reliability program in the Wisconsin Public Service territory. So we're going to finish the first phase and do a second phase that will be about $100 million. That's a very popular program. We've seen quite significant reliability benefits for the distribution customers in Wisconsin Public Service. On the gas distribution side, just to give you 1 example, I'm sure you and the other listeners on the call are very familiar with what's going on with and the new rules that are coming on gas storage. We believe we're going to require about a $50 million program at the [indiscernible] Storage Field in Illinois to do well work and to put in the subsurface safety valves. So that's another $50 million. And then just to give you a couple of other examples, a number of software projects that we believe are going to results in [indiscernible] so short cycle work management system in Illinois. We're also going to move to automated meters in our Michigan Gas Utility as well as Minnesota Gas Utility. So as you could tell, from that listening, I mean, there's quite a number of things that are in that list and I believe, our team believes they're be beneficial to customers either from a cost standpoint or reliability or both.

componenttext: Got it. One other thing, if I think about what's kind of going on in the various businesses and I know you updated capital spending, but your CapEx outlook at ATC kind of has a little bit of a mini-cliff, meaning CapEx has elevated and then another year, 1.5 years from now, it kind of decline significantly down to the $400 million level or so at the ATC consolidated level. Do you still see that happening? Do you see anything in the horizon that could drive much of an uptick at ATC that could kind of fill that? Or you just simply expect ATC growth to slow down a bit?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me talk about that, Michael in 2 pieces. So inside the footprint, when I say inside the footprint, that would be inside Wisconsin and ATC, Michigan. You're right, you're going to see or where we expect to see somewhat a deceleration or a lowering
componenttext: Yes, let me talk about that, Michael in 2 pieces. So inside the footprint, when I say inside the footprint, that would be inside Wisconsin and ATC, Michigan. You're right, you're going to see or where we expect to see somewhat a deceleration or a lowering in this spending at ATC. However, if you look at the 10-year numbers, the last cycle when they updated their 10-year plan, there was 3.7 to 4.5. This cycle, it's 3.6 to 4.4. So if you look over a 10-year period, the 10-year numbers aren't that different. But in terms of the annual averages, those are, I would expect, they're going to come down somewhat, Michael, because the very, very large, very, very significant reliability projects inside the footprint, a lot of those are done. Now as perhaps as generation patterns change in the state because of Clean Power Plan, perhaps you could see an uptick again but right now, we expect it to come down somewhat. So that's inside of footprint. Outside the footprint, we're certainly pursuing other investments. We talked about on previous call, we talked about that a little bit. So that's one of the reasons why a number of years ago, because of what we sow coming inside the footprint file you want to start pursuing some things outside of Wisconsin and Michigan.

And then just to reiterate what I was signed earlier in the call, we would start having those conversations early in the new year with the staff.

componenttextpreview: Well, just to be clear, so this is related to methane leaks from the gas distribution system in Chicago. And my understanding of the approach that the team uses there to prioritize projects, it already takes into account leak rates, methane leak rates. So
componenttext: Well, just to be clear, so this is related to methane leaks from the gas distribution system in Chicago. And my understanding of the approach that the team uses there to prioritize projects, it already takes into account leak rates, methane leak rates. So there's already the attempt to build into that process, that variable, if you will, and trying to reduce methane leak. So I would view that we're already trying to address that in the way we do the prioritization. Certainly, if there's a better, more precise way to factor that into the process, that's certainly something we could consider but it's already being considered in the current prioritization process.

componenttext: Yes. So maybe just sort of go back because a lot of people may not have the history with the point beach with the PTA and with the sale of the asset. So I'm sure you remember, Andy, but for the benefit of others on the call, so back in 2000 -- actually December of 2006, we announced the sale of the plant and some associated PPAs with Xterra. We went through a very protracted, contested case proceeding in Wisconsin leading up to the actual financial closing of the sale in 2007. Now during that protracted or long contested case proceeding, the commission approved not only the sale of the nuclear plant so 2 units, both of the units but they also reviewed and approved the PPAs. And there were refunds of the above booking of the proceeds in the plan does well as of the excess decommissioning funds that were in the trust. So the PPA as well as the sale all were reviewed in that proceeding. And then ever since then, these PPA payments has been consistently recovered in the fuel clause. So I think all that background, or that context is important and I think Scott, maybe you could fill in, I don't know if you have specific numbers in terms of the lease for the next 2 years, what happens, I don't have them handy.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome to WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2016 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in this presentatio
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and welcome to WEC Energy Group's conference call for third quarter 2016 results. This call is being recorded for rebroadcast. [Operator Instructions]
Before the conference call begins, I remind you that all statements in this presentation, other than historical facts, are forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties that are subject to change at any time. Such statements are based on management's expectations at the time they are made. In addition to the assumptions and other factors referred to in connection with these statements, factors described in WEC Energy Group's latest Form 10-K and subsequent reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission could cause actual results to differ materially from those contemplated. During the discussion, referenced earnings per share will be based on diluted earnings per share unless otherwise noted.
After the presentation, the conference will be open to analysts for questions and answers. In conjunction with this call, a package of detailed financial information is posted at wecenergygroup.com. A replay of our remarks will be available approximately 2 hours after the conclusion of this call.
And now it's my pleasure to introduce Allen Leverett, President and Chief Executive Officer of WEC Energy Group.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our results for the third quarter of the year. But first, I want to introduce the members of our team who are with me here today: Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, our T
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. Thank you for joining us today as we review our results for the third quarter of the year. But first, I want to introduce the members of our team who are with me here today: Scott Lauber, our Chief Financial Officer; Jim Schubilske, our Treasurer; Susan Martin, our General Counsel; Bill Guc, our Controller; Beth Straka, finally, our Senior Vice President of Corporate Communications and Investor Relations.
So with that, let's start with our third quarter 2016 results. We reported adjusted third quarter earnings of $0.69 per share. That compares with adjusted earnings of $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Our adjusted earnings exclude merger-related costs. The weather here in Southeastern Wisconsin was the second warmest in 84 years. Scott will review the most significant drivers for the quarter with you in a moment. 
In addition to our third quarter earnings, we have 2 positive developments to share with you. First, we reached an uncontested settlement with the Michigan Public Service Commission staff, the Michigan attorney general and other intervenors to form a Michigan-only utility. This utility will be named the Upper Michigan Energy Resources Company or UMERC for short. We expect UMERC will provide electric and natural gas service to current customers in Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. At this point, we believe UMERC will begin operations on January 1 of next year. 
The formation of UMERC is another step that is required to allow us to begin a certificate of necessity proceeding for our proposed generation solution in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. We are proposing a $255 million investment in 170 megawatts of natural gas-fired generation. UMERC would own and operate the reciprocating internal combustion engines, which would provide a long-term generation solution for reliable and low-cost power for customers in the Upper Peninsula, including the mines owned by Cliffs Resources. Now we expect to file our proposal with the Michigan commission in November, and we're targeting commercial operation in 2019. At that time or soon after, we expect to be in a position to retire our coal-fired Presque Isle Power Plant. 
 
The second positive development relates to our earnings outlook. Based on the positive third quarter results, largely driven by weather, we now expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our guidance range of $2.88 to $2.94. 
Now we only had 1 ongoing rate case this year. This was our Minnesota gas utility's rate case. There, we recently received final decision from the Minnesota commission authorizing a 9.11% return on equity. The revenue increase is approximately 3% or an estimated $6.8 million. And this is in line with our expectations for the case. Early next year, we will evaluate our rate case plans for all of our utilities. 
Next, I want to mention a recent development at the FERC level which impacts our earnings at ATC. On September 28, FERC voted to affirm a prior ALJ recommendation of a 10.32% base ROE in the first MISO ROE complaint. Effective January 2015, we qualified for a 50 basis point adder for being a MISO member, increasing our ROE to 10.82%. The resolution of this first complaint for the period from November 2013 through February 11 of 2015 resulted in an increase in pretax earnings of approximately $1.4 million. 
Looking ahead, we expect an order in the second quarter of 2017 in the second MISO complaint case where the ALJ recommended a base ROE of 9.7%. Again, we qualified for the 50 basis point adder, which would increase the recommended ROE to 10.2%. We believe this is an appropriate assumption going forward. 
Now a reminder on our dividend. In January of this year, our board declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.495 a share, an increase of 8.2% over the previous quarterly dividend. Our annual dividend rate stands at $1.98 a share, and our yield is at approximately the industry average. We continue to target a payout ratio of 65% to 70% of earnings. Given that we are in this range now, I expect our dividend growth will be in line with our earnings per share growth.
Finally, I want to review our updated 5-year capital forecast. This plan now reflects a range of $9 billion to $9.5 billion, which is $1.6 billion more than the plan we presented at EEI last November. This plan does not include a potential natural gas storage investment that we are continuing to pursue. I would also remind you that these figures do not include ATC's capital spending plan. In addition to the projects outlined for you earlier, we have continued to identify the need for infrastructure improvements, including our gas facilities in Chicago. We have included updated 5-year capital investment forecast charts in the back of the earnings packet.
Now with details on our third quarter results and a financial outlook, here's our Chief Financial Officer, Scott Lauber.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Allen. Our 2016 third quarter GAAP earnings were $0.68 per share compared with $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Third quarter results in both 2016 and 2015 include a full quarter of earnings from the Integrys companies. Excluding
componenttext:
Thank you, Allen. Our 2016 third quarter GAAP earnings were $0.68 per share compared with $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015. Third quarter results in both 2016 and 2015 include a full quarter of earnings from the Integrys companies. 
Excluding 1 set of acquisition costs in 2016, adjusted earnings per share increased by $0.11 from $0.58 per share in the third quarter of 2015 to $0.69 per share in the third quarter of 2016. You may recall that we reported adjusted earnings of $0.61 per share in the third quarter last year. 
For purposes of comparing 2016 and 2015 third quarter earnings on a consistent basis, the calculation of adjusted earnings per share for the third quarter of 2015 now include Integrys' earnings, all interest expense related to the acquisition financing and all shares issued in conjunction with the acquisition. As a result, the comparable adjusted earnings per share value for 2015 is now $0.58 per share. The earnings packet placed on our website this morning includes the results of the Integrys companies and its full GAAP to adjusted reconciliation. 
First, I'll focus on operating income by segment and then discuss other income, interest expense and income taxes.
We're turning to Page 10 of the earnings packet. Our consolidated operating income for the third quarter adjusted for costs related to the acquisition of Integrys was $402.5 million as compared to $351.8 million in 2015, an increase of $50.7 million. 
Starting with the Wisconsin segment. Operating income in the third quarter totaled $299.1 million for 2016, an increase of $42.5 million from the third quarter of 2015. The improved quarter-over-quarter results for the Wisconsin segment was driven primarily by significantly warmer-than-normal weather and timing of positive fuel recoveries. 
In the third quarter of 2016, our Illinois segment had $11.7 million of operating income, an increase of $8.2 million compared to the $3.5 million of operating income recognized during the 2015 third quarter. The increase in operating income was driven primarily by continued investment in the gas system modernization program.
Operating income for our other states segment improved $2.7 million, in part due to cost controls. Operating income at the We Power segment was up $500,000 when compared to 2015. This increase reflected additional investment at our Power the Future plants. Our corporate and other segment realized adjusted operating loss of $1 million this quarter compared to adjusted operating income of $2.2 million in the third quarter of 2015.  Taking the changes of these segments together, we arrive at $50.7 million increase in adjusted operating income. 
During the third quarter of 2016, earnings from our investment in American Transmission Company totaled $38.3 million, a decrease of $1.7 million from the same quarter last year. The lower equity earnings were driven by the recent FERC order and ALJ recommendations related to the ATC ROE reviews. Our other income net decreased by $3.6 million, largely related to lower AFUDC, which was caused primarily by timing of capital expenditures. 
Our net interest expense decreased $4.1 million. Interest expense decreased quarter-over-quarter primarily as a result of the repurchase of a portion of the Integrys 6.11% union notes earlier this year. Those notes were replaced with lower-interest-rate, short-term debt.
Increased quarter-over-quarter operating income was the primary driver for the $15.7 million increase in our adjusted consolidated income tax expense. We anticipate that our annual effective tax rate for 2016 will be between 37.5% and 38.5%.
Combining all of these items brings us to adjusted earnings of $219.1 million or $0.69 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared to $185 million or $0.58 per share for the third quarter of 2015. On a year-to-date basis, GAAP earnings were $2.35 per share compared with $1.78 per share for the 9 months ended September 30, 2015. Excluding acquisition costs, adjusted earnings per share increased $0.33 from $2.03 per share in 2015 to $2.36 per share in 2016. Year-to-date results in 2016 include the impacts of the Integrys acquisition. Recall that 2015 year-to-date results include only 1 quarter of Integrys earnings.    
Net cash provided by operating activities increased $647.5 million during the first 9 months of 2016. This increase was driven primarily by $526 million of net cash flows from the operating activities of Integrys for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016. The remaining increase was driven by a decrease in contributions to employee benefit plans. As previously discussed, we contributed $100 million to our qualified pension trust in 2015, and we did not make a contribution in 2016.
Our capital expenditures totaled $1 billion during the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, a $208.3 million increase compared to the same period in 2015. The largest increase was related to capital investments at the Integrys companies. Our debt-to-capital ratio was 51.4% at the end of September, an increase from the 50.1% adjusted debt-to-capital ratio reported at the end of June. 
Effective at the end of the third quarter, we no longer are adjusting equity for any portion of the legacy Integrys hybrid instruments. Our calculations continue to treat half of the WEC Energy Group 2007 Series A junior subordinate notes as common equity. We are using cash to satisfy any shares required for 401(k) plans, options and other programs. Going forward, we do not expect to issue any additional shares. 
We also paid $468.6 million in common dividends during the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, an increase of $157.7 million over the same period last year. Higher dividends were driven by the increase in shares outstanding related to the Integrys acquisition and an increase in the dividend rate compared to the first 9 months of 2015. Since the beginning of 2015, we increased our quarterly dividend 17.2% from $0.4225 per share to the current level of $0.495 per share. 
Moving to sales. We continue to see customer growth across our system. At the end of September, our Wisconsin utilities were serving about 7,000 more electric customers and nearly 13,000 more natural gas customers compared to a year ago. Our natural gas utilities in Illinois, Michigan and Minnesota are serving approximately 18,000 more customers compared to a year ago.
Now let's discuss delivered volumes. For comparative purposes, year-to-date electric volume information reflects results for both Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service. Weather-normalized deliveries are adjusted to factor out the effects of leap year. Actual third quarter retail electric deliveries, excluding the iron ore mines, increased 4.1%. On a weather-normalized basis, retail deliveries of electricity were flat compared to the third quarter of 2015.
Looking at the individual customer segments. Actual residential deliveries rose 8.1% while weather-normalized residential deliveries decreased 0.5%. Across our small commercial industrial group, actual deliveries increased 3.6% while weather-normalized quarterly deliveries increased 0.7%. In the large commercial and industrial segment, deliveries for the third quarter of 2016 increased 2.2%. Excluding the iron ore mines, large commercial and industrial deliveries increased 0.8%. We see continued improvement in several important sectors of Wisconsin's economy, including paper and paper products, food processing and chemical processing. Year-to-date weather-normalized retail deliveries, excluding the iron ore mines, increased 0.3%. 
Now an update on our natural gas deliveries. As you may recall, our Illinois segment has a decoupling mechanism and its margins are less affected by weather. Looking at Wisconsin, our largest segment, year-to-date retail gas deliveries, excluding gas used for power generation, decreased 3% compared to the same period in 2015 due primarily to normal weather. On a weather-normalized basis, year-to-date retail gas deliveries, excluding gas used for power generation, were up 2.8%. Overall, our normalized results for gas and electric sales in 2016 were slightly above our expectations. 
Turning now to our earnings forecast. We expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our guidance of $2.88 per share to $2.94 per share. The guidance excludes $0.01 per share of acquisition-related costs in the third quarter as well any potential acquisition-related costs that may arise during the fourth quarter. This projection assumes normal weather for the balance of the year and reflects the mild first quarter weather as well as the very warm third quarter weather conditions.
A couple of key points as we look at the annual guidance. First, the very warm weather in the third quarter was mainly in Southeastern Wisconsin, and the majority of the weather-related margins and positive fuel recoveries were in the Wisconsin Electric service territory. This was a benefit to Wisconsin Electric in the third quarter of about $0.08. As you recall, Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas have an earnings sharing mechanism in place as part of the acquisition order and, therefore, limit the overall earnings potential for the year.
In addition, we expect an increase in maintenance expense items in the fourth quarter compared to last year. Again, we expect our 2016 earnings to be at the upper end of our $2.88 per share to $2.94 per share guidance range. 
With that, I'll turn things back to Allen.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Now before we take your questions, I want to take a moment to thank Colleen Henderson for her 21 years of dedicated service to the company. Now it's been my pleasure to work with Colleen for 13 of these 21 years. Colleen will be retiri
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Now before we take your questions, I want to take a moment to thank Colleen Henderson for her 21 years of dedicated service to the company. Now it's been my pleasure to work with Colleen for 13 of these 21 years. 
Colleen will be retiring from the company in January. Colleen has been our primary contact with all of you as well as the other members of the investment community. She leaves a legacy of what I believe is one of the best Investor Relation programs in our industry. So please join me in wishing Colleen a long, happy and healthy retirement.
Operator, we're ready for the question-and-answer portion of our conference call.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I do have a question on the fourth quarter earnings and then a question on CapEx. So first, you guys earned -- I think you've earned $0.63 in the fourth quarter last year. So if I just do the basic math, if you had flat year, you'd be slightly abov
componenttext: The -- I do have a question on the fourth quarter earnings and then a question on CapEx. So first, you guys earned -- I think you've earned $0.63 in the fourth quarter last year. So if I just do the basic math, if you had flat year, you'd be slightly above the high end of the range. Is the reason that you don't expect that to happen because you'll be in a refund position on the sharing or because you've found opportunities to do accelerated expense programs with a benefit to customers or some combination of both? Or is there another item that I'm not thinking about?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start, Greg, on the fourth quarter earnings question, and then I'll let Scott expand on a couple of points. So you touched on one of the issues, which is the sharing mechanism at Wisconsin Electric. When I say sharing mechanism, the earnings sha
componenttext: So let me start, Greg, on the fourth quarter earnings question, and then I'll let Scott expand on a couple of points. So you touched on one of the issues, which is the sharing mechanism at Wisconsin Electric. When I say sharing mechanism, the earnings sharing mechanism at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas. And just to keep in mind, that's about 60% of our regulated utilities. So 60% of our earnings would be subject to that earnings sharing mechanism. So we certainly expect that mechanism to kick in and there would be some sharing. In fact, we already approved some sharing in the third quarter. So that's the first factor that will impact -- we expect will impact the fourth quarter. You've touched on that. The other thing, Greg, that I would just emphasize, and Scott talked about this a little bit in his remarks, but remember, the electric fuel recovery mechanisms that we have at Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Public Service, they have a dead band. So in dollar terms, it's a plus or minus $15 million at Wisconsin Electric, it's a plus or minus $6 million at Wisconsin Public Service. And so once you get above those positive recovery levels, all of the dollars go, dollar for dollar above that level, back to refunds for customers. Unlike the third quarter of last year, we actually went all the way to the top of those bands in the third quarter of this year. In the fourth quarter of last year, we had to get well into the fourth quarter before we hit those levels. So that also will introduce another timing difference or earnings timing difference, if you will, in third quarter as opposed to fourth. And the last thing is related to O&M spend. And what really happened, Greg -- it seems like every quarter we talk a lot about the weather, but in the fourth quarter of 2015, that was a very mild weather quarter. And as a result, in order to hit the financial commitments we had, we actually had to cut back a bit on O&M spending. So I view the O&M spend run rate that we had in the fourth quarter of 2015 as being a little abnormal, meaning abnormally low. What I think we'll see in the fourth quarter of this year is more of a normal run rate for the business the way it's configured now. So I think those 3 factors, the earnings sharing mechanisms, hitting the top of the positive recovery bands on fuel in the third quarter and, finally, that difference on O&M timing, I think all of those will impact the fourth quarter. I don't know, Scott, if you want to spend any time at all on the sharing mechanisms.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We can just cover that just a little bit. So Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas have the sharing mechanism. And remember, there's an authorized or allowed return in Wisconsin Electric of about 10.2% ROE and then we share the first 50 basis points a
componenttext: Yes. We can just cover that just a little bit. So Wisconsin Electric and Wisconsin Gas have the sharing mechanism. And remember, there's an authorized or allowed return in Wisconsin Electric of about 10.2% ROE and then we share the first 50 basis points above that. So we can theoretically earn up to the 10.45%. And then anything above that or the sharing part of it will be used to basically amortize some of the transmission assets that we have on our balance sheet. That was part of the acquisition order. So that's part of the sharing mechanism that will happen in -- as we look at the fourth quarter again and tie it altogether. The -- as we look at the earnings in the fourth quarter last year, if you factor in the interest expense, it's about $0.62 on a comparable basis. And the fuel that Allen talked about, that's about $0.03. So you get down to that $0.59. And the O&M getting back to a normal run way --- rate and maintenance is about $0.02 to $0.03. So it gets into that $0.57, $0.59 range.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Greg, I think you also had a question on capital.
componenttext: So Greg, I think you also had a question on capital.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the -- you did mention it in your comments at the opening of the call. Can you talk a little bit more about specifically what kind of projects you've identified? I think at this point, you've pretty much fully offset the $1 billion impact of bonus
componenttext: Yes. So the -- you did mention it in your comments at the opening of the call. Can you talk a little bit more about specifically what kind of projects you've identified? I think at this point, you've pretty much fully offset the $1 billion impact of bonus depreciation from the tax package that was passed last December. And I think you've even -- if I count them, 2000 -- increases in the 2019 and 2020 CapEx forecast have now basically gotten back into the sort of positive territory on total rate base additions relative to the impact of bonus. So can you talk about where you are in your -- sort of in your thought process on updating your CapEx? You said there's still -- A, what are the things that you put into the plan that you think are beneficial for customers? And B, what is still being -- you talked about, I think, at least 1 type of capital program that's still under consideration that hasn't been rolled out yet.

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. Well, in terms of the way the numbers break down, so overall, if we look at our 5-year capital plan, it's about $1.6 billion more than the plan that was laid out in November of 2015 at EEI. So you're exactly right, Greg. It would offset the $
componenttext: Right. Okay. Well, in terms of the way the numbers break down, so overall, if we look at our 5-year capital plan, it's about $1.6 billion more than the plan that was laid out in November of 2015 at EEI. So you're exactly right, Greg. It would offset the $1 billion -- roughly $1 billion cash impact of bonus depreciation plus another, say, $550 million on top of that. So just to give you a sense for the types of things, Greg, that are in the $1.6 billion. So we alluded to one of them in the call, so there's $255 million for the generation in Michigan. I certainly see that as a benefit to the customers in the UP and also a benefit to the customers in Wisconsin because once we retire Presque Isle, there'll be about a $40 million O&M savings associated with retiring that plant. Also, in the generation category, we've made the assumption -- we also expect that as soon as we can or we're allowed to by MISO, we want to proceed to retire the Pulliam plant, which is a coal plant in the Green Bay area. And that will leave a generation need in Wisconsin Public Service, and we'll have an option to invest. We have a generation option to the Riverside power plant that Alliant is building. That's about $100 million. So exercising that first option. On the electric distribution side, I think we've talked before about the system modernization and reliability program in the Wisconsin Public Service territory. So we're going to finish the first phase and do a second phase that will be about $100 million. That's a very popular program. We've seen quite significant reliability benefits for the distribution customers in Wisconsin Public Service. On the gas distribution side, just to give you one example, I'm sure you and the other listeners on the call are very familiar with what's going on with FEMSA and the new rules that are coming on gas storage. We believe we're going to require about a $50 million program at the Manlove storage field in Illinois to do well workovers and to put in the subsurface safety valves. So that's another $50 million. And then just to give you a couple of other examples, a number of software projects that we believe are going to result in O&M savings, so short-cycle work management system in Illinois. We're also going to move to automated meters at our Michigan gas utility as well as Minnesota gas utility. So as you could tell, from that list, I mean, there's quite a number of things that are in that list. And I believe, our team believes that they'll all be beneficial to customers either from a cost standpoint or reliability or both.

But mainly, the Southeastern Wisconsin was about 50% warmer than normal, so quite an extreme warm weather over the quarter.

componenttext: One question. If I look at the year-to-date numbers in the earnings packet, one of the things that doesn't really stand out a lot is the impact of O&M, right? So the -- when you give kind of the small verbal -- not verbal, the small written descriptions on Page 11 of what's the contribution at each segment to potentially lower O&M, it's actually not that big of a number, and that strikes me. Just at first glance, a little bit surprising given you're not even 1.5 years post merger. And just curious, is that being embedded somewhere else? Or are you not seeing much in the way of O&M reductions post Integrys? Trying to just think this through a little bit.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, there is some O&M sprinkled throughout, so we are seeing O&M in all the different segments, Wisconsin, Illinois, the other states. And remember, Allen talked about some of the sharing mechanism and that we booked a little bit in the quarter, about $18 million. So that is actually an acceleration of transmission costs, so that is buried in that O&M number also.

componenttext: Got it. One other thing, if I think about what's kind of going on in the various businesses, and I know you updated capital spending, but your CapEx outlook at ATC kind of has a little bit of a mini cliff, meaning CapEx has elevated. And then another year or 1.5 years from now, it kind of declines significantly down to the $400 million level or so at the ATC consolidated level. Do you still see that happening? Do you see anything in the horizon that could drive much of an uptick at ATC that could kind of fill that? Or do you just simply expect ATC growth to slow down a bit?

headline: WEC Energy Group, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me maybe talk about that, Michael, in 2 pieces. So inside the footprint -- when I say inside the footprint, that would be inside Wisconsin and the UP in Michigan. I mean, you're right, you're going to see -- or we expect to see somewhat of a dece
componenttext: Yes. Let me maybe talk about that, Michael, in 2 pieces. So inside the footprint -- when I say inside the footprint, that would be inside Wisconsin and the UP in Michigan. I mean, you're right, you're going to see -- or we expect to see somewhat of a deceleration or a lowering in the spending at ATC. However, if you look at the 10-year numbers, the last cycle when they updated their 10-year plan, it was 3.7 to 4.5. This cycle, it's 3.6 to 4.4. So if you look over a 10-year period, the 10-year numbers aren't that different. But in terms of the annual averages, those are -- I would expect they're going to come down somewhat, Michael, because the very, very large, very, very significant reliability projects inside the footprint, a lot of those are done. Now as -- perhaps as generation patterns change in the state because of Clean Power Plan, perhaps you could see an uptick again, but right now, we expect it to come down somewhat. So that's inside the footprint. Outside the footprint, we're certainly pursuing other investments. And we talked about -- on previous calls, we talked about that a little bit. So that's one of the reasons why a number of years ago -- because of what we saw coming with inside the footprint, why we wanted to start pursuing some things outside of Wisconsin and Michigan.

componenttext: Yes. And then -- so maybe just sort of go back because, I think, a lot of people may not have the history with Point Beach, with the PPAs and with the sale of the asset. So just -- and I'm sure you remember, Andy, but for the benefit of others on the call, so back in 2000 -- actually, December of 2006, we announced the sale of the plant and some associated PPAs with NextEra. We went through a very protracted, contested case proceeding in Wisconsin leading up to the actual financial closing of the sale in 2007. Now during that protracted or long contested case proceeding, the commission approved not only the sale of the nuclear plant, the 2 units, so both of the units, but they also reviewed and approved the PPAs. And there were refunds of the above booking -- of the proceeds that we got above booked to the plan as well as the excess nuclear decommissioning funds that were in the trust. So the PPA as well as the sale all were reviewed in that proceeding. And then ever since then, these PPA payments have been consistently recovered in the fuel clause. So I think all of that background, all that context is important. And I think, Scott, maybe you could fill in. I mean I don't know if we have specific numbers in terms of at least the next 2 years, what happens with the PPA rights. I don't have them handy.
